author: bridge-bot
content:
<CarlBeek> @kobigurk 
0. awesome that youâ€™ve started taking a look, but note that thee specs are not complete yet. there is still a bunch of stuff that i need to add, but feedback is appreciated

1. i donâ€™t think thatâ€™s a mistake. the new participants append to the list so we require that the lists are the same up to the last element.

2. aah, i hadn't thought about such an attack, i was hoping that we could get away without the participants verifying anything for speed reasons. (or at least have them verify it after their contribution). hmm, i'll need to rethink that strategy.

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> can you be more precise about that aydin attack @kobigurk ? surely if coord adds an extra element that would be detected as the setup didn't have the right length

author: bridge-bot
content: <CarlBeek> and do we know any low order elements for bls?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kobigurk> *simplified version

*H = low order element

current state:
tau G, tau^2 G, tau^3 G

coordinator changes it to
tau G + H, tau^2 G, tau^3 G

contributor has secret x

contributes

x*tau G + x*H, x^2*tau^2 G, x^3*tau^3 G

since contributor doesn't verify correctness of transcript and subgroup checks (at least not yet written in the spec), they don't catch it

coordinator tries to remove x*H by iterating i=0...order i*H and checks for subgroup membership each time

gets x mod order of H as result

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> but this would not ultimately produce a correct result

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> hmm I guess it could work if it is done to another than the tau^1 element

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> but yeah agree we need to add subgroup checks

author: bridge-bot
content: <kobigurk> > <kobigurk>  it would - you just remove the bad element by the coordinator (re @dankrad: but this would not ultimately produce a correct result)

author: bridge-bot
content: <CarlBeek> or we could have participants sign the hash of the input and output transcripts

author: bridge-bot
content: <kobigurk> > <kobigurk>  ah but yeah you could do it to any element (re @dankrad: hmm I guess it could work if it is done to another than the tau^1 element)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kobigurk> > <kobigurk>  but you check previous_transcript minus last element equals new_transcript

thought it would be new_transcript minus last element equals previous_transcript (re @CarlBeek: @kobigurk 
0. awesome that youâ€™ve started taking a look, but note that thee specs are not complete yet. there is still a bunch of stuff that i need to add, but feedback is appreciated

1. i donâ€™t think thatâ€™s a mistake. the new participants append to the list so we require that the lists are the same up to the last element.

2. aah, i hadn't thought about such an attack, i was hoping that we could get away without the participants verifying anything for speed reasons. (or at least have them verify it after their contribution). hmm, i'll need to rethink that strategy.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <CarlBeek> oh! yes that is a bug

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kobigurk> >  awesome that youâ€™ve started taking a look, but note that thee specs are not complete yet. there is still a bunch of stuff that i need to add, but feedback is appreciated

no problem :) if it's not useful to look at yet, I'll hold off! lmk

author: bridge-bot
content: <CarlBeek> no-no, i appreciate having eyes on it, just noting that there is still a fair amount of work still to do

author: bridge-bot
content: <kobigurk> yep I know

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kobigurk> also just a general comment - you can optimize the verification of the transcript by checking correct ratios only on the last result from the transcript

but this requires some guarantee that the individual checks (subgroup, non-zero) have been done on the intermediate transcripts as well

making participants do them is a good way to do it

in retrospect I regret to not have done that in the celo ceremony

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> So thinking again, there is a security guarantee that comes from commitments without degree checks. They are still binding. So for example, for EIP-4844, that would still provide perfect security (it does not rely on correct encoding). So maybe there is nonzero benefit from starting with filecoin
